title: Are there elderly people who can learn how to use new technologies easily? - Quora

response.answer_text: If by “old” you mean those over 40 - then certainly. They abound, you meet them everyday and probably report to one, or your boss does. If on the other hand you mean people over 90 - no. Our UI’s are too stupid for them. “Old” means deteriorating physical coordination that starts in your 70’s. Most “new” technologies require good vision to handle increasingly complex interfaces, high levels of manual dexterity for typing, tapping or making gestural signals. This - combined with an array of complex menu options (Think- Not Alexa) require users to navigate a complicated menu tree that often fails to produce the desired results. While the pre-pubescent set will pound away until they have chased down every rabbit hole, the elderly take this as a sign you don’t really want then to do any useful work and give up. In Japan - with the focus on an aging society - interfaces are smarter, simpler with fewer choices and much more intelligence behind the screen than in front to anticipate and react quickly to the needs of “The Silver Set”. Not so much in the US. Complexity is not the sign of a great interface designer. Ask Jony Ive.

If by “old people” you mean people in their 50’s, then there are definitely people who can easily learn to use new technologies. I’m in my 50’s and I’m far better at learning new technology than I was in my 20’s, because I have the benefit of 30 more years of learning and perspective that I can apply to every new technology. (Hint: Most “new” technology is just a slight tweak to old technology.) If by “old people” you mean people in their 80’s or older, then there are definitely people who can easily learn to use new technologies. I know folks in their 80’s who regularly use new gadgets, software, mobile apps, and Web sites. Age really has nothing to do with ability to learn, but experience does make learning easier. I suspect the stereotype of old people being unable to learn new technology is because they’re unwilling to learn new technology; not because they can’t, but because they’ve got better things to do.

Bruno you snarky punk. I am 70 and gertting ready to hold two workshops this month alone and I will be holding classes starting on May 2020 through The University Of Texas Austin adult continuing education for my thirty first year as a teacher and writer. My second manuscript will publish in 2020, the first “Boxcar Tourist/How I Screwed My Nut”, was published five years ago. “No Sympathy For The Devil,” a tale of televangelisits who mad a deal with the devil so the female leader can be more powerful than God himself. How is that for an old fu*k Bruno?

Sure. N.B. above 70, the natural aging takes its toll and many start getting problems with daily life. Genetics and how well you lived and live (slept, exercised, socialized) affects the risks of aging. A few example of old people who love technology: Dagny Carlsson - Wikipedia (107 years old blogger), see also This 104-year-old blogger is keeping the dying art alive(In Swedish), a video interview with Alice who participated in a project with active technology at home.
Elderly people have no trouble learning new technologies, but they often don’t feel motivated to do so, as they usually have stable and happy lifestyles already and don’t require or desire changes.
There are some, but with age many faculties (i.e. thinking) become slower and more difficult.
